p: CMV-specific CD4 + T cells are thought to play an important role in containing CMV infection, and in mouse models, CD4 + T cells were abundant in infected peripheral tissues ( Reuter et al., 2005; Verma et al., 2015). A reduction in the CD4:CD8 ratio in healthy young CMV + adults, which has also been reported in other studies ( Turner et al., 2014), could be caused by a reduction in circulating CD4 + T cells as they are recruited to peripheral sites of infection. As infected individuals age, multiple reactivation events over many decades cause a gradual expansion of CMV-specific CD8 + T cells, which then become the prominent factor driving the CD4:CD8 ratio down ( Hadrup et al., 2006).
